  1 module Haml
  2   # This class is used only internally. It holds the buffer of XHTML that
  3   # is eventually output by Haml::Engine's to_html method. It's called
  4   # from within the precompiled code, and helps reduce the amount of
  5   # processing done within instance_eval'd code.
  6   class Buffer
  7     include Haml::Helpers
  8 
  9     # Set the maximum length for a line to be considered a one-liner.
 10     # Lines <= the maximum will be rendered on one line,
 11     # i.e. <tt><p>Hello world</p></tt>
 12     ONE_LINER_LENGTH     = 50
 13 
 14     # The string that holds the compiled XHTML. This is aliased as
 15     # _erbout for compatibility with ERB-specific code.
 16     attr_accessor :buffer
 17 
 18     # Gets the current tabulation of the document.
 19     def tabulation
 20       @real_tabs + @tabulation
 21     end
 22 
 23     # Sets the current tabulation of the document.
 24     def tabulation=(val)
 25       val = val - @real_tabs
 26       @tabulation = val > -1 ? val : 0
 27     end
 28 
 29     # Creates a new buffer.
 30     def initialize(options = {})
 31       @options = options
 32       @quote_escape = options[:attr_wrapper] == '"' ? "&quot;" : "&apos;"
 33       @other_quote_char = options[:attr_wrapper] == '"' ? "'" : '"'
 34       @buffer = ""
 35       @one_liner_pending = false
 36       @tabulation = 0
 37 
 38       # The number of tabs that Engine thinks we should have
 39       # @real_tabs + @tabulation is the number of tabs actually output
 40       @real_tabs = 0
 41     end
 42 
 43     # Renders +text+ with the proper tabulation. This also deals with
 44     # making a possible one-line tag one line or not.
 45     def push_text(text, tabulation, flattened = false)
 46       if flattened
 47         # In this case, tabulation is the number of spaces, rather
 48         # than the number of tabs.
 49         @buffer << "#{' ' * tabulation}#{flatten(text + "\n")}"
 50         @one_liner_pending = true
 51       elsif @one_liner_pending && one_liner?(text)
 52         @buffer << text
 53       else
 54         if @one_liner_pending
 55           @buffer << "\n"
 56           @one_liner_pending = false
 57         end
 58         @buffer << "#{tabs(tabulation)}#{text}\n"
 59       end
 60     end
 61 
 62     # Properly formats the output of a script that was run in the
 63     # instance_eval.
 64     def push_script(result, tabulation, flattened)
 65       if flattened
 66         result = Haml::Helpers.find_and_preserve(result)
 67       end
 68       unless result.nil?
 69         result = result.to_s
 70         while result[-1] == 10 # \n
 71           # String#chomp is slow
 72           result = result[0...-1]
 73         end
 74         
 75         result = result.gsub("\n", "\n#{tabs(tabulation)}")
 76         push_text result, tabulation
 77       end
 78       nil
 79     end
 80 
 81     # Takes the various information about the opening tag for an
 82     # element, formats it, and adds it to the buffer.
 83     def open_tag(name, tabulation, atomic, try_one_line, class_id, obj_ref, flattened, *attributes_hashes)
 84       attributes = {}
 85       attributes.merge!(parse_class_and_id(class_id)) unless class_id.nil? || class_id.empty?
 86       attributes.merge!(parse_object_ref(obj_ref, attributes[:id], attributes[:class])) if obj_ref
 87       attributes_hashes.each { |h| attributes.merge! h if h }
 88 
 89       @one_liner_pending = false
 90       if atomic
 91         str = " />\n"
 92       elsif try_one_line
 93         @one_liner_pending = true
 94         str = ">"
 95       elsif flattened
 96         str = ">&#x000A;"
 97       else
 98         str = ">\n"
 99       end
100       @buffer << "#{tabs(tabulation)}<#{name}#{build_attributes(attributes)}#{str}"
101       @real_tabs += 1
102     end
103 
104     # Creates a closing tag with the given name.
105     def close_tag(name, tabulation)
106       if @one_liner_pending
107         @buffer << "</#{name}>\n"
108         @one_liner_pending = false
109       else
110         push_text("</#{name}>", tabulation)
111       end
112     end
113 
114     # Opens an XHTML comment.
115     def open_comment(try_one_line, conditional, tabulation)
116       conditional << ">" if conditional
117       @buffer << "#{tabs(tabulation)}<!--#{conditional.to_s} "
118       if try_one_line
119         @one_liner_pending = true
120       else
121         @buffer << "\n"
122         @real_tabs += 1
123       end
124     end
125 
126     # Closes an XHTML comment.
127     def close_comment(has_conditional, tabulation)
128       close_tag = has_conditional ? "<![endif]-->" : "-->"
129       if @one_liner_pending
130         @buffer << " #{close_tag}\n"
131         @one_liner_pending = false
132       else
133         push_text(close_tag, tabulation)
134       end
135     end
136     
137     # Stops parsing a flat section.
138     def stop_flat
139       buffer.concat("\n")
140       @one_liner_pending = false
141     end
142 
143     # Some of these methods are exposed as public class methods
144     # so they can be re-used in helpers.
145 
146     # Takes a hash and builds a list of XHTML attributes from it, returning
147     # the result.
148     def build_attributes(attributes = {})
149       result = attributes.collect do |a,v|
150         v = v.to_s
151         unless v.nil? || v.empty?
152           attr_wrapper = @options[:attr_wrapper]
153           if v.include? attr_wrapper
154             if v.include? @other_quote_char
155               v = v.gsub(attr_wrapper, @quote_escape)
156             else
157               attr_wrapper = @other_quote_char
158             end
159           end
160           " #{a}=#{attr_wrapper}#{v}#{attr_wrapper}"
161         end
162       end
163       result.sort.join
164     end
165 
166     private
167 
168     # Gets <tt>count</tt> tabs. Mostly for internal use.
169     def tabs(count)
170       @real_tabs = count
171       '  ' * (count + @tabulation)
172     end
173 
174     # Iterates through the classes and ids supplied through <tt>.</tt>
175     # and <tt>#</tt> syntax, and returns a hash with them as attributes,
176     # that can then be merged with another attributes hash.
177     def parse_class_and_id(list)
178       attributes = {}
179       list.scan(/([#.])([-_a-zA-Z0-9]+)/) do |type, property|
180         case type
181         when '.'
182           if attributes[:class]
183             attributes[:class] += " "
184           else
185             attributes[:class] = ""
186           end
187           attributes[:class] += property
188         when '#'
189           attributes[:id] = property
190         end
191       end
192       attributes
193     end
194 
195     # Takes an array of objects and uses the class and id of the first
196     # one to create an attributes hash.
197     def parse_object_ref(ref, old_id, old_class)
198       ref = ref[0]
199       # Let's make sure the value isn't nil. If it is, return the default Hash.
200       return {} if ref.nil?
201       class_name = ref.class.to_s.underscore
202       id = "#{class_name}_#{ref.id}"
203 
204       if old_class
205         class_name += " #{old_class}"
206       end
207 
208       if old_id
209         id = "#{old_id}_#{id}"
210       end
211 
212       {:id => id, :class => class_name}
213     end
214 
215     # Returns whether or not the given value is short enough to be rendered
216     # on one line.
217     def one_liner?(value)
218       value.length <= ONE_LINER_LENGTH && value.scan(/\n/).empty?
219     end
220   end
221 end
222 
223 unless String.methods.include? 'old_comp'
224   class String # :nodoc
225     alias_method :old_comp, :<=>
226     
227     def <=>(other)
228       if other.is_a? NilClass
229         -1
230       else
231         old_comp(other)
232       end
233     end
234   end
235     
236   class NilClass # :nodoc:
237     include Comparable
238     
239     def <=>(other)
240       other.nil? ? 0 : 1
241     end
242   end
243 end
